title: Strange...But With Heart
content: The best thing that "Edward Scissorhands" has going for it is that it was directed by Tim Burton, perhaps the only man who could make this story move us. Unfortunately, Burton is also this film's biggest downfall by intermixing his cinematic and stereotype gobbledegook into the overall plot.For a basic plot summary, this film sees a boy named Edward (Johnny Depp), who has scissors instead of normal hands, brought down from his lonely, deserted castle to live in suburbia. After all the appropriate hijinks such a situation perpetuates, Edward falls in love with his new family's daughter Kim (played by Winona Ryder), which only further complicates matters.The reason this isn't an "instant classic" despite the never-before-seen concept and compelling visuals? For almost three quarters of the movie, director Burton (as is his style) mishmashes all sorts of stereotypical human themes and doesn't make sense of any of them. It is all just a jumble & mess. It's kind of like "Being John Malkovich", in a sense, where the concepts and visuals are the movie, not the actual plot itself.How can I enjoy this movie, then? Because, in the end, it truly is about love and having a big heart. For me, when everything else falls aside and the focus is squarely on Edward & Kim is where this film will move you. Ryder is able to perfectly capture the essence of youthful beauty, while Edward is a character for whom sympathy is a must. Their moments on screen together (combined with a wonderful score from Danny Elfman) are spectacular and worth the viewing time alone.Overall, this is a decent film that will always be remember for its unique concept and title character. Don't try to understand all its message, but instead focus on the human elements: love, family, & hope. If you can do that, you will care about what happens in the end.

title: Beautifully done!
content: I loved this movie. It was really cute and had a good storyline. It's a perfect film companion to movies like Beauty and the Beast or Shrek. The script was well-written and Johnny Depp was brilliant as Edward. Although he didn't have many lines, he portrayed his role with such emotion and by the end of the movie, it was no surprise to find tears in my eyes. Does Edward look different? Yes. But you can't help but love him. At a quick glance, the movie seems to be "scary" but really, it's not. The imaginative land of Surburbia and Dianne Weist's character had me laughing throughout the film. This was really an excellent movie and I definitely recommend it!

title: Unusual man upsets the ordinary folks
content: Here's this brand new looking subdivision that has an old Dracula looking mansion atop a hill which no one seems to know anything about. How could all the strange goings-on in this totally bizarre appearing domicile go unnoticed until the Avon lady calls? Why is it that the nutty professor could get all the body parts for razor boy but had trouble coming up with a pair of hands? I can think of several other body parts that would be more troublesome to find than hands. Would a good looking girl really[come on now]go for someone with scissors  growing out of his wrists? Finally, why was Edward so retarded that he failed to take care of the redhead in back of the future salon? He did have all the necessary tools, didn't he?

title: Pointless and Mean-Spirited
content: Everybody gets all excited over this movie...not me. I never liked this movie and for good reasons. The concept is horribly executed. We have a sweet guy with scissors for hands and people take advantage of him in the most cruel ways. If you're going to be mean-spirited about it, have it get resolved in a satisfying way for your audience. How can you have a conflict that makes the experience unwatchable? Not only was this piece of garbage painful to watch, but there is nearly zero redeemable qualities about it.The overall message is awful and when the guy gets treated like crap, no one does anything to stop it. It basically tells us that if you get mistreated, just kill the jerks and everything will be okay. Seriously, this is one of the most overrated movies ever made and people are oblivious to how unimportant it is. I'm giving it 2/10, because I did like the sets and costume design. Other than that, avoid this like the plague!

title: A Wonderful Film
content: Edward Scissorhands has become a film classic and a favorite to watch around the holidays (Christmas/Yuletide) for many people. It's a very nice story of a scientist and his "son" Edward. Edward was not completed before his father-creator died so he is left with scissors for hands.Peg sales Avon and ends up going to the home of Edward. She has a bleeding heart for him and brings him back home with her to live. Ed falls in love with her daughter Kim but Kim's boyfriend is extremely jealous and mean towards Kim as well as others... this causes friction in the community.The movie is a light-hearted romantic comedy-drama (dramedy). It's colourful and dark at the same time. It's just an all around good movie.Note: This is Vincent Price's last significant film.8.5/10

title: you'll laugh, you'll cry, you'll love
content: I finally got round to seeing this movie, and I absolutely loved it, it is really one of a kind! Like most people I read fairy tales when I was little and this modern fairytale is just as great as any of those the Grimm brothers wrote.Edward is a great character which, like most of his roles, Johnny Depp plays excellently. I found myself giggling at how adorable and innocent he was with his actions, yet almost in tears at how tragic it was to see him sad and the ways he was treated. The great thing about the film is how it plays with your emotions like that, and as with most great fairy tales, includes some kind of moral. The dark edge to it makes the film that more mysterious, definitely one of Tim Burtons greatest movies. A timeless classic.

title: "Innocence is what he knows, beauty is what he sees"
content: THE masterpiece of the master himself, Tim Burton!In the beginning you get a strange feeling when you see the setting of the village and the behavior of the people who live in it. You soon realize that this is not going to be the standard movie that you are used to watch. When Edward (Johnny Depp) appears, you just know for sure that this will be a special movie. What follows is a magical spectacle about an extraordinary man who can do extraordinary things with his scissors as fingers. A movie full of humor, tolerance and love. It seems like a place where everything is perfect... until the drama strikes and everything that I just summed up will be in jeopardy.Let me talk about Johnny Depp. Does it still have to be said that Johnny Depp is the most fantastic actor to play this kind of role? I don't like to see him play roles that are ordinary and close to the usual, but I see him so eager to play roles that have something abnormal.The vision of Tim Burton, the acting of Johnny Depp and the soundtrack of Danny Elfman ensure that this is the family film that you can watch on Christmas Day. Every time, it leaves a warm feeling that won't escape you!

title: With all due respect

title: Unique
content: So there are lots of good film makers out there. Stars in each genre. Action, drama, romcom, gross out..... Just one simple question What category is Edward Scissorhands in? Tim Burton and his team created something unique. The story at one level is a romance of a girl with an outcast. It is the story of the power of the esoteric over the mundane. It is a parody of the shallowness of 50s America. It shows the surreptitious power of wives over wage slave husbands. It has elements of fairy tale. It has elements of comedy. It has elements of tragedy. They all combine to make a unique, enchanting, stunning, unmissable film. Without a doubt this is top ten movie magic - the man shows his genius here.

title: Edward Scissorhands-An Endless Classic
content: Edward Scissorhands, from Tim Burton, feels like a fairy tale, or a fable, or a dream of some sort. Even today, after 30+ years, it elegantly combines Edward's cold, dark background with lighter elements like love, discovery, family, and self fulfillment. It balances the scary aspects of being lonely for years with the warm relief of finding your place. It has a very mature tone to it as Edward's mind and personality evolve, making him very much relatable today.Edward Scissorhands is more than a movie-it's pure Tim Burton poetry! It's all about a humanoid robot developing a heart that's bigger than him!

title: Bittersweet is the best kind of movie.
content: When I was little girl of four, a wonderful movie premiered on the big screen. That movie was called "Edward Scissorhands". Having once watched "Nightmare on Elm Street" (still as a little four year old) in the dark of night with my parents, the idea of Scissorhands just didn't appeal to me. So for the next fourteen years, I avoided and shied away from every golden opportunity to see the film. I ALWAYS thought it was a horror flick. But one day, as a high school graduate of eighteen, I decided to watch a little bit of it with my mother before heading to work. I fell in love immediately! That little bit I saw was the funniest thing I had viewed in a very long time. I hadn't laughed so hard since I still can't remember when.So during my lunch, I rented the DVD. When I got home late that night, I popped it in right away. And although I still laughed hysterically at my favorite parts (waterbed scene...all-time favorite!), I was almost moved to tears by the end of the film. With the combination of Tim Burton's excellent directing skills and Danny Elfman's heart-wrenching movie score this movie has become one of my very favorites. Because if a movie has a happy ending, I'm upset by it's cliché qualities, and if it has a sad ending, I don't ever want to watch it again, but when a movie has a bittersweet ending, the good and bad emotions I feel are so jumbled that I can't help loving the film.

title: Cutting Edge: Brilliant acting Conchata $$$$
content: Edward Scissorhands was a beautiful masterpiece.  Never has one felt so connected to Johnny Depp.  His character was very charismatic, and the film was very warm and gave me a sense of security and well-being.But that's enough about Johnny. The true star of this film was Conchata Ferrell by far. Her role as Helen was brilliantly portrayed and ever so realistic. Of course my theory is that Teen Angel is really the high point of her career.  I believe that an actress like Conchata is definitely more suited to roles like Pam on Teen Angel, but before that, this was truly a magnificent early role for her.By the end of this film, I felt more in touch with myself and my feelings for others.  I learnt to understand that cruelty to people is terrible and that when one is shunned by society as I myself am, it helps to see films like this and realise that these movie producers care about more than profits.Edward Scissorhands was, after American Beauty, the best film I have ever seen in my life.  Good work Tim and keep making more films like this one!A 10 out of 10 for this one!!

title: A strange sense of wonder
content: It took me quite a while to appreciate this film - mostly because I wasn't familiar with Burton's fabulous, overblown proportions and great vision. "Edward Scissorhands" was just too weird for me. I am happy to say that it has grown on me - though being far from Burton's later work, such as "Ed Wood" or "Sleepy Hollow", it is still strikingly original and is a very interesting experience.The tidy, perfect and very unreal suburb in contrast to the dracula-style castle that has somehow been left standing right in the middle of it is just the sort of dreamy juxtaposition that one could expect from Burton. It is a treat to be surprised by it and it feels very novel. The nosy, in-your-face housewives who center their absurd lives around what's going on in the neighborhood are a vital part of this juxtaposition. It makes you wonder which part of this weird place is for real and which isn't. And Edward himself, a bizarre freak whose life is turned upside down by kind and unkind (and just plain dumb) suburban dwellers - Edward must be one of the most haunting and sad characters I have ever seen, and Depp is absolutely perfect for the part.In many respects the characters are pretty normal - they have been tweaked somewhat to allow for their extravagant behavior and their calculating meanness, but other than that, they are just people. But put in these awful, cheerily colorful surroundings, they seem even more twisted than they already are. And Edward, apart from his appearance, is more normal than any of them. A film full of wonders. It's inspiring to think that Tim Burton thought this movie up as a kid.

title: Tim Burton masterpiece

title: The Strange World of Tim Burton
content: I'll start this off by saying I am not a die-hard Tim Burton fan. I don't love "Big Fish", I hate "Batman Returns", and I can't say I have ever watched "Pee-Wee's Big Adventure" all the way through. That said I want it known that I am devoted to "Batman", I can't help but love "The Nightmare Before Christmas" and "The Corpse Bride", and "Sleepy Hollow" is one of my guiltiest pleasures. Even though Tim Burton doesn't always deeply impress me I do know that he is easily one of the most interesting contemporary filmmakers. And I can say without reservation that "Edward Scissorhands" is one of the most touching and enchanting films I've ever seen. After reading a very negative review of this beautiful film, from legendary critic Roger Ebert, I decided that it was necessary to comment on the only true masterpiece to be issued entirely by Tim Burton's imagination.Lets start with the premise of the movie. A young man with scissors for hands is taken in by a suburban family and falls in love. Can any idea be any further away from Hollywood formula? The very fact that this film was made is a testimony to Burton's power in Hollywood in the early 90s (post-Batman he could do anything I guess).Ebert's remarks seem to center on how Burton has great ideas but he simply lacks the ability to tell a story well. Nothing could be further from the truth. The plot, aside from the scissors for hands part, is rather clichéd. We've all seen this plot a dozen times. "Troubled youth is adopted by a kind family and tries to fit into a new community." Hell, if you removed Edward from the script and slapped in a stock troubled teen you would instantly have a so-so teen angst picture. Get Rob Reiner to direct it and we have a ready-made sequel to "Stand by Me". Really the only reason Edward Scissorhands is remarkable is because, before "Planet of the Apes" mind you, Tim Burton was probably the most original director making big-budget films in America. His unique visual style and artistry made this film great, just like they did Ed Wood and "Beetlejuice". Even "Batman" (a film I will always love) is nowhere near the caliber of this film. And what especially attracts me to this film is that Burton here, more than any other film he's made, is very obviously pointing out how formulaic and conformist all other studio films have become (notice this in his depiction of suburbia and compare). He's also just plane making fun of the suburban lifestyle, and as a kid from the suburbs I have to laugh, because he's absolutely accurate in his vision.It's rare to find a movie with a remarkably distinct visual style, a wonderful narrative, and actual social commentary to boot. Somehow Burton managed to have it all in the most unlikely of stories. This film proves that movies which defy standards and accounting practices are the only ones which can be adored, and I will always remember it as Tim Burton's biggest success. Also it ended Vincent Prices' contribution to films while simultaneously launching Johnny Depp's career. In retrospect it really should have won an Oscar for something.

title: Hard as rock, sharp as scissors, soft as paper - 'Edward Scissorhands'
content: Being director Tim Burton's picture 'edward Scissorhands' combines a sense of dreamy storytelling with great special effects.  The film tells the story of edward, a young, mysterious man with a different appearance but a kind human heart.Edward lives alone in the town's notorious 'house on top of the hill' until the day an Avon lady calls and takes him home to live with her in their town...unfortunately not realising the potential consequences.As always the director (Sleepy Hollow, Beetlejuice, Batman) works visual magic and with a top screenplay by Caroline Thompson the film captivates with a slight twist on good and evil.  With spectacular sets, Tim Burton, uses a fantastic, surreal mixture of dark, haunting sets and bright planned 60's streets.  These sets are stunningly visual and vibrant colours play off each other and contrast to edward's dark yet beautiful home)Starring a then trapped TV drama heart-throb, Johnny Depp (edward) gives a performance of a lifetime without really having to speak.  His heart-warming performance enables you to sympathise with this character and his habits, such as extravagant topiary and makes you also sympathise with how difficult people are to get on with in life.  Johnny Depp is among a fine cast including Winona Ryder, Diane Wiest and Vincent Price as the inventor.The other characters, mainly the family and the neighbours start to annoy you with their precise lives but soon it becomes apparent that this is the danger for the harmless edward.  As in a lot of Tim Burton films the characters are obviously greatly worked into and can sometimes seem a derivate on stereotypes or to the extreme.  Whatever your view, this works in 'edward Scissorhands' and adds to the tragedy that affects anyone who isn't 'normal'.Some people may find the start a little slow but that does not hinder the fascination throughout the film and I find this also shows the quick descent into sad chaos as the characters begin to realise the consequences of trying to change things. `Sometimes you just can't change things.' The film doesn't really have a set time period because with love it doesn't matter.The story is original and gently funny, with a slight touch of danger. This film, to me, also represents the narrow mindedness of our societies and touches upon the notion of racism and discrimination and the sad consequences of the extremes of this.  It is shown through the family's neighbour's reception to edward.  Above all though the film is about true love and works under the children's question 'where does snow come from?' - The film answers the question, you will have to see it to find out.For me 'edward Scissorhands' is the best visual journey ever told.  With make-up from Stan Winston and music by Danny Elfman, the whole film takes you into a spectacular surreal world.  'edward Scissorhands' is an incredible love story, visually a treat and one that will remain in your heart forever.Star rating - five out of five

title: Beautiful and Haunting
content: Edward Scissorhands is one of those movies that doesn't fit any sort of mold, yet still manages to to touch people on so many levels. It's funny, sad, romantic, and scary all at once. Alternating tears and laughter, there are few movies do it this brilliantly. Boasting great performances from Dianne Wiest, Anthony Michael Hall, Winona Ryder, and the incomparable Johnny Depp it shows both the best and worst of human nature and does it beautifully. Tim Burton creates a setting that draws you into another world, all the time seeming like complete reality. It's a story about a man who was invented and is one day taken to suburbia by a kind Avon lady. Combining classic fairy tale elements with brutal reality it becomes a story about acceptance and love. Truly unique, and one of my favorites, Edward Scissorhands is simply a classic.

title: Enjoyable Fun watch!
content:
This movie originally made in 1990 is another staple in Tim Burton's timeline of enjoyable, fun, and environmentally original pieces of work. Though the story is bogged down by cliche conflicts and sometimes annoying plot devices this movie is still a great work of art and a prime example on how Burton's style flows though a movie. But Burton's style though bright and fun sometimes lacks on the story side of the coin. Characters seems sometimes come off flat and have unclear motives. The movie focuses on one neighborhood and how the residents come to see and accept this very different person into their lives. This is an interesting idea for a movie but it not totally original or done well in some areas.
 
Overall, Burton's sometimes boiled down, cliche story can bring down the movie but his patented Burton style still helps it rise it above others in its genre. A joyful ride with good performances all around.

title: Absurdity vs Normality
content: Edward Scissorhands is a deeply peculiar and philosophical story that questions the peculiarity of life. It is a story that challenges people's ideas as to what is considered strange versus what is considered normal, and how by calling something strange or normal is really just a prejudice that identifies itself with the other side. In other words, what one person calls normal is what another may call strange. People typically use the word "strange" to alienate themselves from that which they don't understand, or are afraid of. The truth of the matter is that everything and everyone is strange; which is to say, everyone and everything is not completely understood, each of us being quintessentially unique. We have to familiarize ourselves with the strange and welcome it with open arms in order to understand ourselves, others and life in general better. The story of Edward Scissorhands is no different.Edward is a part machine part man whose creator dies before his completion, leaving him with scissors for hands. He lives life as a social outcast within the vacant walls of a lonely, deserted castle, and is one day invited to live a "normal" lifestyle amongst a neighborhood of gossipy Suburban folk. He timidly accepts the offer, descends from his gloomy abode and enters a world that is not entirely familiar to him. He gawks inquisitively out car windows, jolts when telephones ring, pokes the mirror to examine the reflection he sees, struggles to eat food like everyone else, and overall lives in this new world like a foreign yet wondrous traveler. As the Avon lady who gave him this invitation concludes, "It'll take some time to getting used to Edward before you start feeling at home." Profound are these words. They seem to strike at the very core of the pilgrim within us all; traveling like foreigners on an unfamiliar planet as we try and familiarize ourselves and search for the cure to our divine homesickness.That which we typically familiarize ourselves with to a great degree we call "home", or comfort. Conveniently for us we have quickly grown accustom to our home since birth. Earth is our home, and it is a place that has become familiar to us through repetition and time. For an individual like Edward, howeverone whom many of us would view as alien because of his differenceshe, to the contrary views our home as alien, and if you really stop to think about it, he's right.The film's objective correlative seems to argue that it's OK to view life as absurd. Life is absurd. Life's absurdity will hopefully motivate us to learn more about what we are a part of, and to make that which was once considered absurd seem more reasonable. This only happens by descending, like Edward, from our homes of comfort and discovering the beauty that lies within the unknown. I believe we all bask in our own private wonderlands that at times make sense, and other times make nonsense. We're all still so naïve about who we are, where we came from, why we're here and where we're going, that to call something strange, I think, would be an indirect compliment to the God who created us all. It just means that we haven't explored enough. With time and repetition, however, things will become more familiar until we reach the status of feeling like we've finally arrivedfinally made it home.Edward Scissorhands is truly a wonderful story that reminds all of us not to lose our child-like ingenuities, but to embrace fear with loving hands and a confident smile.

title: Still a great movie...
content: I have indeed watched the 1990 movie "Edward Scissorhands" several times over the years, and needed no persuasion to sit down and revisit it here in 2024, just to brush up on it.The storyline in the movie is a well-written and entertaining story. Writers Tim Burton and Caroline Thompson put together a unique, memorable and outstanding script and storyline to be sure. And it definitely is something that you would expect to come from the mind of Tim Burton. I enjoy the story told in the movie, as it is a wonderful fantasy tale mixed with some light comedy, a touch of Frankenstein, dark romance, and of course the archetypical Tim Burton touch.Of course the acting performances in the movie are good. And why wouldn't it be? With the likes of Johnny Depp, Winona Ryder, Dianne Wiest, Kathy Baker, Conchata Ferrell, Alan Arkin and none other than Vincent Price. The cast was great for this movie, and somehow the symbiosis of a Tim Burton movie with Johnny Depp in a leading role is something that just goes hand-in-hand.The movie is not without its flaws and issues, though. I have to admit that I am a bit perplexed with the bush situation in the neighborhood. Because in order for Edward to sculpt such huge sculptures from people's bushes in their yards means that people have had some pretty huge bushes growing in their yards, and they must have been quite some eyesores. And I don't recall seeing bushes that big in the neighborhood when Peg was running her Avon rounds. And that old, crumbling ruin of a manor at the end of the street stood out like a sore thumb, very much a dark and bleak contrast to the pastel colors of the sunny neighborhood, but again it just didn't make much of any sense for a neighborhood to be placed directly up against such a looming ruin. Not to mention how Edward would get food in the time passing since the inventor died. But hey, it is just a movie.Visually, I will say that the movie is definitely a classic Tim Burton movie, complete with the dark, gothic and over-the-edge style of imagery that he is known for, be it in animated movies or live action movies. Edward was definitely an interesting character in design and appearance, and the special effects team definitely made the scissors look real.If you haven't already seen this 1990 Tim Burton movie, then I would definitely recommend that you should do so, if you get the chance. It really is an enjoyable and entertaining movie, not to mention a memorable storyline. I will actually say that "Edward Scissorhands" ranks up there as one of Tim Burton's best movies.My rating of director Tim Burton's 1990 movie "Edward Scissorhands" lands on a seven out of ten stars.

title: Edward Scissorhands
content: I hadn't purposely made the decision to neglect the works of Tim Burton, yet I found myself in 2017, despite being a huge cinema fan, without ever seeing a Tim Burton feature before in my life. It was time to rectify this oversight and settle in for Edward Scissorhands. The 1990 film starring Johnny Depp and Winona Ryder exploring the life of an abandoned invention turned man left alone when his inventor passes away before he is finished. Burton had a lot to say in Edward Scissorhands, very obviously, criticizing suburban culture and the social constructs of what constitutes as "normal". His message is clear and nearly overtakes the narrative coming off as an after-school special. Nevertheless, it was time to finally "meet" Tim Burton.On the edge of the most picturesque suburban town, there is a castle that no one visits, and the neighbors know nothing about. Inside the castle, there lived an inventor (Vincent Price) responsible for elaborate designs taking over the entire castle. His most prized invention is that of Edward (Johnny Depp). He built a man, called Edward, a person made from parts, complete except for that of his hands. His hands were left as scissors before the inventor passed away. Since his inventor's passing, he lived alone in the castle secluded from the world and left to fend for himself. Trying to see Avon products, a kind neighbor named Peg (Dianne Wiest) happened upon the castle, finding Edward. At first, Peg is frightened by Edward and his scissor hands, but she eventually understands that he is a gentle soul yearning for some human interaction. Peg decides that she can't bear to leave Edward behind, so she invites him into her family's home. Initially, her family and neighbors are taken aback at the sight of the pale, scarred, man with scissors for hands. Eventually, though, Peg's friends and family come around, and once they get to know Edward, they realize he is sweet and unique and has talents appreciated by all. After such acceptance, however, things start to go wrong and the easiest person to blame is the different outsider.Tim Burton obviously hates suburbia, the entirety of Edward Scissorhands is his diatribe of all the problems of suburbia. He was so overt with his message that suburbia traps people, keeping them confined and limited. Burton also clearly illustrates how much being different is looked down upon, to an almost nauseating intensity. The camera angles Burton chose to use, while they were effective in creating the claustrophobic atmosphere he was going for, were uncomfortable to watch. The ratio created with the camera work he chose seemed too manipulative to appreciate. Johnny Depp was overkill with his expressions, taking one out of the film by being so distracting. The standout was the score/sound design, in an otherwise after-school special-like film far too overt with its message and seeming to make color/camera angle decisions for the director's own pleasure rather than for the audience.

title: Stay away from pushy Avon sellers!
content: Edwards Scissorhands is definitively not your average Christmas movie, but your average Tim Burton movie, so it evens out. It is an exploration of a bizarre world where creativity and imagination overflow, an invitation to accept and celebrate each other's differences, but also a metacommentary on everyday life in the good ol' American suburbs. The ending can leave a bad taste in your mouth if you are looking for a typical happy-ending Christmas flick to watch with your family, but I do not think it takes away anything from the film.As with other Tim Burton movies, we can appreciate the contrast between light and darkness; on the one hand, we have the colorful neighborhood where Peg (Dianne Wiest) and her family live, while on the other, we have the somber castle where Edward spends his days by himself; we see it too with the neighbors, willing to accept Edward as one of their own, while also being quick to judge him when things go south.The highlight of the film is Johnny Depp's outstanding performance as Edward, portraying a man-made human being with a heart of gold does not seem something easy to pull off, but Johnny Depp passed with flying colors. Bravo!A film worth watching and rewatching, I definitively recommend it.

title: One of the best films ever.
content: When Tim Burton and Johnny Depp have worked together on a film, its never a disappointment. I cried during this film, it's so beautiful yet so quirky and dark. Johnny does and incredible job (as usual). He always puts his heart and soul into every character, what a special actor. Edward's character is so amazing,he's so lovable and innocent. I absolutely love Winona Ryder as Kim, brilliant actor too. Soundtrack to this film is also wonderful. 'Ice Dance' & 'Farewell' are the most beautiful pieces. The ending to this film is also very lovely. Acting 10/10, story line 10/10 and soundtrack 10/10. My second favourite Depp & Burton collaboration, after Sweeney Todd.

title: pretty much the best film ever
content: I could watch this film again and again (and I have).It's the epitome of Tim Burton- magical and moving, whilst at the same time having a dark, Gothic edge. It's visually beautiful, powerfully contrasting bright toy-town colours with gloomy greys and blacks. Absolutely everything, from the colours of the houses to the clothes the characters wear, has been carefully thought out so that you have the impression of watching not a film, but a moving painting.The storyline is lovely, and it will make you laugh and cry, often simultaneously. It's a perfect twist on the fairy story genre.One of my favourite things about this movie is the score- composed by Danny Elfman. It fits the atmosphere of the movie perfectly, with its sweeping violin melodies and ghostly female choir. Tender, yet strange.Johnny Depp is, of course, fantastic and in my opinion this is one of his best roles. He barely has any lines but his characterisation remains very strong, meaning that you pretty much fall in love with Edward from the get-go.Just watch this film. You won't regret it.

title: A beautifully crafted film
content: Edward Scissorhands is a film I have been meaning to watch since being influenced by the fairytale storytelling of 'Big Fish'. Tim Burton has yet ceased to impress me (despite the fact that I have not seen many of his films) and I have always recognised Johnny Depp as being an actor who can make any character his own, so I was pleased when the viewing opportunity arose.I have to say that I was not disappointed. The unique aspects of contrast between the bright town and its residents and the dark castle like place where Edward is created is wonderful. The script is well crafted,  sometimes funny and very touching. Burton creates a misunderstood character, much like the famous Frankenstein monster. I believe it near impossible not to feel for Edward when he states lines such as "I'm not finished." Johnny Depp is superb and you cannot help responding to his naive, childlike smile.Although when you read the full story aspects of it may seem slightly ridicules, the overall picture is a wonderful film that has now become a favourite of mine.9.5/10

title: Very Cool Movie
content: This was a very cool movie. The colors were really interesting, each house being a different solid color. Each car being a different solid color but not matching the house color of it's owner.I really cared about Edward. This movie highlights how stupid the average Joe is and how ignorant they are to people that are different. I found myself getting angry at the residents of this town. This is an accurate depiction of the ignorance of people.

title: One of the best movies of all time but not for everyone.
content: I'd have to say right now... not everyone will enjoy this movie. Edward Scissorhands is about knowing you should fit in, you want to fit in, but no matter what, you can't. I'd have to say the people that don't like it just don't understand what the message of the story is and/or they can't identify with it. My parents actually had to persuade me to rent it because i was reluctant but...WOW. In the very beginning how the old Kim said that Edward was left "incomplete and all alone", my heart jolted. Edward Scissorhands was so wonderful! It was beautifully done with all the acting (johnny depp, Dianne Wiest, ANthony Michael Hall, Wynona Rider, etc), of course you can't forget Tim Burton and Danny Elfman! This movie isn't just a comedy or love story, it's so many things... one second it's hilarious the next heart-wrenching. Johnny Depp's Edward Scissorhands character just makes you want to say "Aaaaaaaaaaaawwwwwwwwwwwwwwwww" lol. After seeing it for the first time, after it ended i actually cried and instantly fell in love with it. I often just watch it once a day because it never gets old. I'd have to say that from watching this movie you'd never know it was made in 1990, it looks like it could have been made in 2003. Overall, i'd have to say Edward Scissorhands is a pure timeless classic.

title: I think it's a sad movie
content: I don't think Edward Scissorhands is a good film, the story is good, but the main characters in it are too thin. But I still like it, for Jonny Depp. He is the only one who can act as Edward. Edward is a sad character, so despair, even when Winora says she loves him. Do you see the sadness in his eyes?

title: The magical touch of Scissorhands!!
content: What's did a DVD in ours lives, l had watched a little portion of this movie in the past on TV and didn't able to give my vote, so yesterday l watched it in plenty way and found it wonderful, the genius of Tim Burton is really endless, he created a modern fairy tale to all ages, touching using a boy without malice, indeed a pure heart, when he meets a people he wants make part of a mankind, but the time will prove who really are this normal people, Tim Burton reachs on the target in this fabulous that seems the Beauty and the Beast, great in a dark atmosphere!!Resume:First watch: 1994 / How many: 2 / Source: TV-DVD / Rating: 8.5

title: A Great Movie
content: I love this movie. I never get tired of watching it. I cried the first six times I watched it. Usually movies like this are stupid, but this movie is too sad to be stupid. I really can't stand the neighbors. Yet Jim was an OK bad guy. He didn't absolutely hate the main character right from the beginning like most bad guys.

title: One of my all-time favs!!!!!
content: I LOVE this film so much. The music is without a doubt remarkable! This film brings tears to my eyes everytime i watch it! Johnny Depp is truely one of the greatest actors of our time! He's that kind of guy ppl will mention years and years from now like James Dean or Elvis or what not. And winona looks great in this film! I will always love this film!!!!!

title: Best movie
content: This movie is a dramatic fairytale well told. with the element of "Frankenstein", the imagination of Tim Burton, and the musical talents of Danny Elfman, this is an excellent movie. i might note that i really enjoyed the look of the set. the hand shaped hedge was awesome. i very much enjoyed this movie, and would like to buy it sometime. i tried to tape it but something went wrong. Like i saidA Fairytale well toldTim Burton is a Genius. he is the one who created the well known master piece that is The Nightmare Before Xmas, and beetlejuice. but you probably already know that. combined with Danny Elfman's musical talents, the two are an excellent team.Sincerely,~The jellicle kittens~

title: Heart Warming
content: I have been waiting to see Edward Scissor Hands for months. Partly because of the magical and sad story line, partly because of Johnny Depp. I think he played this role with real ease, how many actors do I know who can play roles like Edward without being too plain and boring? Not Many.The story of Edward Scissor Hands is one of those children's films that even action fans or Horror lovers might enjoy a little. It's such a sweet little tale, full of magic and fantasy, with a little bit of love thrown in.This is a movie I will definitely want to see again because even if it's quite an old film, it still manages to warm our hearts.I applaud Johnny Depp for his fine acting. A most wonderful yet simple movie for anybody to watch. Love it.

title: So wholesome!
content: I loved this movie! It was honestly so wholesome and sweet but also sad. Johnny Depp did a great job in this film. This completely changed my perspective on having something unusual and instead of making me feel insecure about my unusual things now I feel a lot better just after watching a movie! The actors in it were all so good! I loved every minute very much and it made me so happy (especially the ending). This was a very good film and I would definitely recommend. It's a very sweet film that I loved very much and makes me so happy every time I watch it. I've watched this film about 3 times.

title: Funny, touching, GREAT!
content: Edward Scissorhands is an imaginative movie from the incredible mind of Tim Burton. Johnny Deppp Stars as Edward, an artificial man that was created by an inventor. However, the inventor died before he could finish Edward so he was left with scissors instead of hands. For years, Edward lived alone in the inventor's mansion. Until, a kind woman named Peggie (Dianne West) arrives at his mansion selling "Avon" products. Edward goes back with her and falls in love with a beautiful .Edward Scissorhands is a very touching movie that is easily one of Tim Burton's best. It will make you laugh and make you cry. Watch it... soon.9/10

title: And So Depp and Burton Begins
content: If you had to name the most famous director-actor collaborations working in Hollywood today, I would bet Johnny Depp and Tim Burton are among the first you would name. Edward Scissorhands was the first film they collaborated on and is probably considered by most to be their best. For me I think the film is a bit overrated. It wants us to believe that this is a man we should all feel sorry for, which we do, but it also tries to convince us that his wrongdoings aren't his fault. While I believe this 'man' deserves to be treated like a human, but I don't think mixing him with other humans and not thinking chaos would eventually happen was the right move.Depp is great as the title role. In fact it's hard to believe anybody else really playing this role. For once he actually gave a tremendous amount of subtly to this strange role and he also gave it a lot of heart. But the problem is that I don't think the supporting characters were developed enough. Not only that, but I don't think any of them actually seem like people who would live in a real world. Perhaps that's the point. Winona Ryder's character has a far too sudden change of mind half way through the film, and her boyfriend is the most clichéd ex boyfriend ever. But I did enjoy watching Depp play this character. And I think his 'mother' had some really great scenes with him as well.So the problem isn't so much the actual story but rather the execution. There are few Burton movies that I thoroughly enjoy so perhaps my problem is more so with him than the rest of the crew. His films tend to be split down the middle with audiences so I think this may be one that I have to sit on and re-watch for further appreciation.+Depp's subtly emotional performance+Dianne West-clichéd characters-Style over substance6.0/10

title: A cut above
content: Edward (Johnny Depp) lives a lonely existence and is isolated in a house set away from the rest of the community. Edward is an outcast because he has had to live his life with scissors for hands after his inventor died before he can finish his creator. Edward is taken in and cared for by a kind woman and falls for her pretty daughter Kim (Winona Ryder). However, things prove tough for Edward as he has to try and deal with disapproving neighbours and Kim's rather aggressive boyfriend Jim (Anthony Michael Hall).Burton's primary objective here was to tell the story of a man who may be a bit scary and weird on the outside, but ultimately show that underneath his rather scary exterior is a man who is kind and gentle. Yes it's a little clichéd and mushy perhaps, but I think it's something that writers can get away with if a film has a certain charm and warmth to it and that's where a film like Edward Scissorhands really succeeds.Another interesting facet with this film is that it acts as a satire/social commentary on suburban life; I must admit that I found it amusing to watch these shallow and dull 'suburban housewives' all chatting on the phone about Edward's arrival and to here them gossiping about their neighbours and so on. It's a spot on critique about modern suburban life that was both clever and funny.Edward Scissorhands is awash with beautiful colours and wonderful cinematography; not only does this film have oodles of charm and heart, but it's also quite pretty to look at as well (and it's not just the cinematography that's pretty - Winona Ryder scrubs up quite well too).As far as performances go then this is Depp's film hands down; he captures both the innocence and naivety of Edward in such a way that it's almost impossible not to care about him as a character. Anthony Michael Hall was surprisingly effective in his role as a thug (I've only seen him play the geek before and must admit that I think he's better playing a geek than a thug, but he was still good here).If I'm being critical then there are one or two weaknesses with this picture; firstly I felt that this film could have benefited from a little more character development (the suburban housewives were quite funny at first, but I do believe that they out stayed their welcome and towards the end they were becoming more annoying than funny). I felt that Burton could have perhaps developed Edward's character a bit more as I couldn't help but feel that he only scratched the surface with his original and impressive creation.To be honest though when a film has this much charm, this much warmth and this much likability it's hard to really put it down. It's pretty to look at, it has a nice story and it contains some fine acting performances. It's a very difficult film not to like so just sit back and enjoy!!

title: Only the first half is good
content: I'd cut this movie into two parts, the first half and the second half. The first half is a solid 9 or even 10 but the second half is 2 at best.After the mid part of the movie it drags on and on and on, piling on more and more unnecessary drama and unnecessary tension, one thing after another goes wrong, one thing leads to another and the whole magic of the movie and the main character are gone and you can't wait for the movie to end so that the poor guy's misery is over.Tim Burton is great at making half-movies but he's not that great at coming up with a good ending. His stories always drag on too much and the endings are never satisfying. The only thing satisfying about this movie's ending is that it finally ended and the suffering is over.

title: A tale of woe, longing, love and fantasy
content: When you hear of fairy tales, you think dragons princesses and horror. But what Tim Burton does here is make a fairy tale that people can relate to, a modern, meaningful story.Edward is a creation that was isolated from the near by suburbs when his inventor died. But, when a thoughtful Avon Lady finds him and takes him home with her.As the plot thickens, the town's people struggle to handle the hands of Edward.This film is a classic and has a moral which is unmissable. "Never judge a book by its cover." Edward is a part of us that has once been. Apart that feels different and abnormal.A truly moving and beautiful film!

title: An Impressive, Excellent Movie by Tim Burton
content: Edward Scissorhands is an excellent movie, brilliantly conceived by Tim Burton and Caroline Thompson. Everything from the wonderful cast, to the amazing score by Danny Elfman, to the interesting script, make for a phenomenal movie-viewing experience.The movie is about Edward (Johnny Depp), a man created by an inventor. However, before the inventor is finished with his creation, he dies, leaving Edward with razor sharp, scissor hands. Left alone, he has no contact with the outside world or other people until the local Avon lady, Peg (Dianne Wiest) decides to drive up to the old, almost deserted, mansion for one last chance to sell her products. Instead she finds Edward. She decides to take Edward away from the mansion and she brings him home to live with her family. Edward now has to learn how to survive in the real world and discover how to live with real people and their prejudices.Johnny Depp does an amazing job as Edward. What makes him so good in this role is his ability to convey so much with so few words. He is clearly showing what it is like to be an outsider and someone who does not quite fit in with the rest of the population. While his 'scissorhands' are good for making beautiful ice sculptures and trimming the neighbors bushes and trees into all sorts of creative shapes, he is not able to perform simple activities like eating a pea. He is also unable to come into direct contact with other humans. He cannot rub his eyes or wipe a hair off his face without cutting himself. Johnny Depp is excellent in portraying this man's difficult and complex life. Edward is completely innocent, yet taken advantage of by everyone simply because he is different. Also notable in the cast are Dianne Wiest, Peg, the Avon lady who brings Edward out of the mansion and Winona Ryder, who plays Peg's daughter Kim.What Tim Burton is able to do extremely well is to create movies that speak to the viewer on some level. Although none of us will ever quite know what it would be like to have scissors for hands, many of us will feel like an outsider at some point in our lives. On some level, we will be able to identify with and sympathize with Edward. Although the situations in many of Burton's movies are fantasy based, it somehow feels real. There is a familiar feeling in his movies, in Edward Scissorhands, Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, and even The Corpse Bride that make the viewer feel as if they are experiencing the events right alongside the characters.

title: absolutely the best
content: My favorite movie of all time. incredibly thoughtful, naive and adorable edward falls into this greedy, all-the-same world of horrible people who want to take advantage of him. script and dialogues incredible, art direction amazing and with my fav duo of all time: johnny depp and tim burton. nothing bad comes out of those two.

title: I can only say... :this film is perfect!
content: Yes. This film is really perfect. It makes you think. It makes you so sad that you want to cry a river and it makes you so happy that you want to jump ten feet in the air- all together. This film is magnificent. The actors, the sets, the music-everything fits together. The story throws you in beautiful dreams. I love this film. I love Edward's pale face and his scissorhands. And everyone who watches this film wants to visit poor Edward in his castle-I can promise, I can guarantee that. We all know now where the snow comes from. And I almost believe that story. It's a pitty there aren't so many of this kind of films out there. But Tim Burton has done a perfect job with this film. I hope "Big Fish" is as good as "Edward Scissorhands".

title: Darkness and pastels; a bittersweet love story
content: In between Batman movies, Tim Burton offered up this unassuming fairy tale, and it's entirely in his wheelhouse. Edward Scissorhands brings the old monster movie to the cookie-cutter subdivision, a place that's ripe for satire. I absolutely love Alan Arkin and Dianne Wiest in this, they don't bat an eye at this knives-wielding misfit as everyone else in town gathers up the pitchforks at the first sign of trouble. Johnny Depp is a believably overgrown child while Winona Ryder (to her credit) sells the romance. This is a fable with a gothic heart; funny, moving and thoroughly entertaining.

title: There's a pink one and a green one and a blue one and a yellow one..
content: "Edward Scissorhands" is a variation on the Frankenstein legend, relocated from Europe to American suburbia, or perhaps I should say to an exaggerated parody of American suburbia. It is presumably set in either Florida or Southern California, as we learn that the ocean is not far away and it is the sort of place where people can walk about in shirt sleeves even at Christmas. The set designer seems to have been given a brief to produce something straight out of Malvina Reynolds' song "Little Boxes". This is a community whose inhabitants do indeed live in little boxes made of ticky-tacky which (apart from colour) all look just the same, and as in the song there's a pink one and a green one and a blue one and a yellow one..Dominating this otherwise flat and boring community is a hill crowned by an eerie Gothic mansion, the home of an elderly, eccentric inventor who, like Frankenstein, is working on an artificial human. Unfortunately, the old man dies before he can finish his creation, whom he has named Edward, leaving him with scissor blades instead of hands. (Why the inventor should have wanted to fit Edward with scissor blades in the first place is never explained, but fantasy is a film genre which enjoys a certain exemption from the laws of logic).The film explains what happens when Edward is discovered by an Avon lady named Peg Boggs and adopted into her family. (Did Tim Burton realise that "bog" is British slang for lavatory?) Although Edward has no hands as we would understand the term, his scissor blades mean that he is an expert at anything involving cutting or chopping, and he is able to earn a living as a hairdresser (catering for both the local housewives and their dogs) and as a gardener, carving hedges into elaborate topiary sculptures. He also has a sideline in ice sculpture.At first Edward is a popular figure in the neighbourhood, but then two incidents turn local opinion against him. Joyce, a middle-aged housewife, tries unsuccessfully to seduce him, and then goes about saying he tried to rape her. Edward is then arrested after Jim, the unpleasant boyfriend of Peg's daughter Kim, tricks him into taking part in a burglary. Although Edward is released, hostility eventually reaches such a point that he is forced to take refuge in his original home, the old mansion on the hill, where he is confronted by an angry mob led by Jim. (By rights Jim should be grateful to Edward, who has never revealed his part in the burglary, but he is jealous of a growing attraction between Edward and Kim).The film begins and ends with an elderly woman telling the story of Edward to her granddaughter; at the end it is revealed that the old woman is Kim Boggs, which implies that these scenes must take place around the year 2050. Burton does not, however, give them a futuristic look; indeed, they look very traditional, emphasising the fairy-tale nature of his story.This is one of my two favourite Tim Burton films, the other being "Big Fish" which also has a leading character named Edward. The two Edwards, however, are very different, as are the films in which they appear, even though both can be classed as fantasies. The Edward of "Big Fish" is much older, a jovial old extrovert, an adventurer and a teller of tall tales, a modern-day Baron Munchausen. "Big Fish" has a happy ending and is outward-looking in the sense that Edward's adventures take him all over the world. "Edward Scissorhands", by contrast, ends poignantly and is inward-looking, with all the action taking place in one small community.This was probably the film which made Johnny Depp a major star, and in my view it remains one of his best performances. He made the role so much his own that it is strange to think that he was not the first choice; that was Tom Cruise, who was not available. Gary Oldman and Tom Hanks both turned down the part; after seeing the completed film Oldman was to state that he regretted his decision. Depp's Edward, unlike his namesake in "Big Fish", is a shy, withdrawn young man, socially awkward and introverted. (His unkempt hair and pallid complexion suggest an affinity with the Goth movement). For all his awkwardness, however, he is good-hearted and capable of love, something which Kim instinctively recognises. (Jim has never loved anyone or anything except himself). The other notable performances come from Dianne Wiest as the kindly Peg and Vincent Price, in his last feature film appearance, as the inventor, who is seen in flashback. Depp's real-life girlfriend Winona Ryder as Kim makes a sweet heroine, although someone should have told Burton that the lovely Winona looks a lot better as a brunette than she does as a reddish blonde."Edward Scissorhands" deals with a number of interrelated themes- self-discovery, the search for personal identity, social conformism, disability, the nature of artistic creativity and the problems of those who are perceived as "different" by society, but fortunately Burton and his co-scriptwriter Caroline Thompson deal with these weighty themes in a relatively light, poetic manner and not in a heavy-handed or preachy one. There is also a fine musical score from Danny Elfman. This is one of those films you can discover more in every time you see it. 9/10

title: Edward Scissorhands
content: A good movie I enjoy watching the movie, Johnny Depp's acting was great, The other actors were not that good, The soundtrack was great, and the story was good until the last 30 minutes.

title: An unsuccessful attempt to parallel a classic.....
content: Edward Scissorhands, desperately trying to imitate the classic movie, Frankenstien, failed completely to capture the emotion and brilliancy displayed by the previous classic. Why someone would want to parallel such a classic like Frankenstein is beyond me.The acting was poor in some places and the characters were very much clichéd. Although, Johnny Debt did portray Edward pretty decently, for it was such a bad part to have, being that Edward was pretty much confused the entire time. I also thought the themes in this movie are overused. I know already that society is unwilling to change and is shadowed by corruption. I didn't need a poorly created movie, being more shallow/unconvincing than creative, to enlighten me on this subject.

title: There is no word for such amazement
content: If there is a movie that has pure magic in it, I would think off the top of my head of Edward Scissorhands. There is simply all innocence and imagination in this film. Burton has created a masterpiece with Caroline Thompson and Danny Elfman as his team. I see now, that while together, they created a film that has all necessitous in it. It contains comedy, crucial to keeping an audience. It contains fantasy, something that all of us have drifted into at least once in our lives. It's nice to view the imagination of another, to see how we relate, because in the end, we find that humans all-together, are not so different. It's the small things that separate us like a titanium wall. I think that was what Burton had tried to do while explaining and creating this film. Also, he had used great actors to capture the innocence or the guilt of their character. Both Johnny Depp and Winona Ryder had played an astonishing act and has led me to believe that there is such beauty in the world.

title: A mysterious, intriguing and uplifting Tim Burton film!
content: This is one film you will have to suspend reality and let your imagination run wild with. Tim Burton directs one of his most iconic films, a story about a man named Edward (Johnny Depp) who was created by a scientist who left him unfinished, leaving Edward a near-complete man with scissors for hands.Edward lives in isolation in a mysterious, dark castle on top of a mountain, which overlooks a quiet, simple, Utopia-like suburb. It's pretty intriguing having an isolated castle located near a normal community, providing a taste of mystery and suspense for the characters in the film and to those watching the movie. When Avon lady Peg (Dianne West) visits the castle in hopes of getting a sale, she instead grows interested in Edward's well-being and brings him back home. It's heart-warming that the kind Peg shows passion to a completely strange person and it's fun seeing Edward show his skills and tricks to the community, from him making grass sculptures to giving the women haircuts with his scissorhands.It is also nice seeing the chemistry between Edward and Kim (Winona Ryder), brilliantly played and uplifting, and the friction between Edward and Kim's boyfriend (Anthony Michael Hall) eventually leads to the more serious misadventures and bad doers in the movie. But, this film shows us that humanity and understanding exist in the world and kind souls do prevail over evil in some way, even though ***spoiler ahead*** not all stories end up happily ever after. I just wished some of the evil-doers got a taste of their own medicine and Edward got cut with some more slack ***spoiler ends***Overall, it's a film with great acting, great music score by Danny Elfman, great direction by Tim Burton and a well-paced story.Grade A-

title: Loveley movie Mr.Burton!
content: Tim Burton is a great director. Over the years he has brought us beautiful works that has filled most heart with joy, compassion, warmth...and he's done all that to me and much more...he has inspired me during my childhood (and he still does)and helped me through my tragic years and times. Tim Burton has made a sweet,lovely film based on his own childhood in Suberbia (Burank). I love this movie,its his most personal piece of work and thats what makes this one special! I just love this movie! Its got everything I love in a movie-wait...I don't know what I love in movies...Well they're all beautiful I guess that's the thing! Well...I hope You get this movie a try because it's beautiful!

title: Depp Should Have Been Oscar Nominated
content: Continuing my plan to watch every Johnny Depp movie in order, I come to Edward Scissorhands (1990)The movie that started the long-running Tim Burton/Depp collaboration. This movie is not just one of my favourite Depp or Burton movies, it's one of my favourite of the decade. I LOVE it.Tim Burton was one of my new favourite directors when he made this. Thanks to Beetlejuice in 1988 and Batman the year after, I was already a fan when he made this classic. I don't think he put a foot wrong for over a decade. And it was this movie, that made me a fan of Depp.Personally, I think Depp should have been nominated for an Oscar. He is superb. In fact, I think Burton, Dianne Wiest, Danny Elfman's score and the movie itself should have been nominated. As it was, it's sole nomination was for Best Makeup.Winona Ryder (who began dating Depp during filming, and would become engaged) is fine and Conchata Ferrell is an actress I adore and Anthony Michael Hall is perfectly cast as the movies bad boy.I think the movie is so touching and moving, it's a joy. Depp himself stated that he "cried like a baby" when he first read the script. At the time of his casting, Depp was wanting to break out of the teen idol status which his performance in 21 Jump Street had given him. Fox executives were so worried about Edward's image, that they tried to keep pictures of Depp in full costume under wraps until the release of the film. To prepare for his role, Johnny Depp watched the films of silent movie actor Charles Chaplin to get an idea of how to emote without dialogue. This would also come in handy a few movies later.Edward Scissorhands grossed $56 million dollars at the domestic box office to end 1990 as the 20th highest grossing movie of the year.

title: Awesome entertainment. A must see!
content: This is one of Tim Burton's absolute Best films. If not his very best of all time. It will make you laugh, cry, and say "aawwww, isn't that cute?" All within minutes of the opening. The story line is very original and emotionally compelling. Tim Burton brings to life all of the milk of human kindness, in the community's ability to accept this less-than-perfect creation. Immediately followed by the all too common judgmental and quick-to-condemn nature of that same group. In this film there are wonderful examples of the human condition, in all senses, the good and the bad, the ugly and the beautiful. If you have not experienced many of Tim Burtons, wonderful and brilliant works, I would recommend that you check out Beetle-Juice(1988), Mars Attacks(1996), Sleepy Hollow(1999), and Big Fish(2003)(one of my most recent favorites!) Next time you rent or buy, keep Edward Scissorhands in mind! I guarantee you wont regret it!

title: Solid
content: Depp's weird likability is at full force here and turns a movie with a story that is a bit off into a movie that is one to remember for sure. It's not one you will run back to but not one you should shy away from.

title: The best movie ever.
content: This movie has got to be the best movie I have ever seen! In fact the story is so beautiful and moving, that I cried when Wiona Rider kissed Jonny Depp. The music in the film helped to...of course! I felt sorry for Edward because he really tried to be nice to everybody by cutting there hair and there bushes and even designed hair stiles for DOGS!!Anyway... I'm glad that he got to feel love! Still... I'm sad because in the end he was still alone and everybody still feared and hated him.If I had to choose the best movie of the century, it would be "Edward Scissorhands". I think this film as a video is also a perfect gift for couples!

title: sad fantasy
content: This is a fantasy film that describes the heartwarming mingling of the android which has a genuine feeling and a human girl. Edward is an android who was produced by an inventor. However, the inventor died suddenly, so he is left alone with metal scissors for hands. After that, a kind saleswoman, whose name is Peg, takes her home with him. In her home, he sees the picture of her daughter, whose name is Kim, and he falls in love with her.Edward is really pure and admirable in spite of his hands are metal scissors. Johnny Depp can play this android nicely. Immediately after Edward comes to Peg's house, he is a general favorite. He makes an effort to bring joy to Kim and other residents of the town. However, he is exiled from there taking advantage of an incident. I thought Edward was really poor because he is apt to be misunderstood by his outward appearance.In addition, the ending is also little sad for him. I thought that there might be other ways of ending.

title: A tragically romantic tale
content: I found Edward Scissorhands to be special in a personal way. The trio of Tim Burton (Director), Johnny Depp (Actor) and Danny Elfman (Music) really comes together to create such a romantic atmosphere in this movie. Depp plays his role well, by keeping the character of Edward as an outcast from humanity and yet making him seem humorous and a character you just fall in love with.Elfman's music really brings this movie to the height of emotion though. The music is often referred to in the music communities I visit and has inspired film music and music in general. The theme song is what I like to call Elf-esque, as it plays those lovely glockenspiel two-key chords, in harmony with the strings and the choir.The symbolism of this movie is superb as well, as you see all of edwards dreams and hopes dashed in his flashback to the death of Vincent Prices character, as his hands are also destroyed.I give this movie a perfect 10, because to me it just brings together all aspects of a movie that are important to me. Emotive, but not over the top music, a lovable lead character played by a good actor, and a the director and producer to pull it off. I recommend this music only to those who are willing to place themselves in a movie and just go with the flow. I'll admit that nostalgia plays a bit part in my like of this movie. But the general romantic tale of Edward Scissorhands just captures my heart in the way that I love. A truly tragically romantic tale.

title: A stranded creation of a lonely master.
content: I found this movie a milestone in my life already at a very young age. It didn't make me cry, because it wasn't an unfamiliar world for me. It felt I lived in it. Instead it made my hands shake that someone, on the other side of the world, a stranger ( a couple of them in fact) have seen the same side of the society we live in. I recognized all the characters from real life. I recognized Peg Boggs in my mother, who also is a naive type of folks, trying to desperately and undoubtedly do good, but doesn't often think before interfering ... I recognized someone on the verge of surrendering to the equalizing, blind rules of the society, then stepping back at the last moment and following her heart in Kim. I Recognized a child who doesn't much argue, hesitate, question or alienate at all, but just acts my the current mood in Kevin. I recognized a creator, who is abandoned by all non - believers, left alone, without any help or good advice, without being kept up - to date , because the society hasn't been patient enough to follow the process of his masterwork. a lot of creators in our world work by themselves. great many fail to be understood and recognized, as is their creation, which is also left stranded, floating in a mass of misconceptions and misinterpretations. what if the creator doesn't explain... what he meant? does the creation have a life in a world where it finds himself?

title: Genius!
content: I saw this one in the theater when I was small, and later many times at home. I never get through it without crying. The score is lovely, never overpowering the story. Edward himself is fragile, yet he had such a desperate nobility to him, and he was so alone...he stands in marked contrast to the apes around him, normal on the outside, but cruel and flawed inside. If you look closely, the neighbors seem to embody one or more of the Seven Sins, while Edward is the tragic innocent.This movie works on so many levels, and still holds up today. Vincent Price shines in his last performance as the Inventor, a small but crucial part that no one else ever would have got right. A truly excellent film, but don't watch it without your hankies ready.

title: Classic Fairy Tale
content: Edward Scissorhands (1990)*** (out of 4)Johnny Depp plays the title character, a nice man who suffers from having scissors for hands. An Avon lady (Diane Wiest) finds him in an abandoned castle and brings him home where he fits in at first but as time goes on he finds it harder to blend in with the normal people. There are a few problems with the screenplay and there are a few logical problems but this is a fantasy so I try to put them out of my head and just sit back and enjoy this rather bizarre film. I think Burton gets across his message about human nature without beating the viewer over the head and in the end this is certainly one of the more memorable films of the decade. Depp is terrific in his role and really brings a lot of truth and sadness to his character. Winona Ryder (whatever happened to her?) is great as well in her role and I've always believed she was one of the best actresses out there in this time frame. The supporting cast of Wiest, Kathy Baker and Anthony Michael Hall also turn in fine work. I love the way Burton used Vincent Price in this film as it turned out to be a very loving tribute to the horror legend. The film is visually striking and the music score by Danny Elfman is terrific. The ending of the film is very touching as well.

title: Fluffy Fantasy That Descends Into Darkness
content: "Edward Scissorhands" is another example of Tim Burton's rather quirky style of mixing humour with horror (in a Goth sort of way) and ending up with a pretty good movie when it's all put together. When I thought about this movie, one of the things that came through was how heavily influenced by the story of Frankenstein it is. Edward (very effectively played by Johnny Depp) isn't a real person, he's a creation of an unnamed scientist (played in basically a cameo role by Vincent Price.) Like Frankenstein's monster, he's basically isolated. Like the monster, when he's removed from his isolation, he ends up wreaking unintentional havoc. Maybe the most obvious comparison is when the people of the town storm the castle he lives in, much like the villagers stormed Frankenstein's castle. (Much of the action in the town actually reminded me of "Desperate Housewives," with everything happening on the same street and a bunch of women being in the know about it all.)The first half of the movie is a fun, whimsical sort of fantasy as Edward tries to adjust to life outside his castle. He becomes the hit of the town (especially with the women.) Some of this is wonderfully funny. Gradually, though, the movie turns progressively darker and even violent as Edward runs into more and more trouble. The gradual shift in tone was very effectively accomplished by Burton, and pulled off well by the cast (especially Depp.) It did, however, represent a bit of a problem for me. The opening of the movie tells us that this story is a bedtime story told by Kim (played by Winona Ryder) to her granddaughter about an event long ago, to explain where snow comes from. I wouldn't think of the darker half of this movie as a good bedtime story for a young girl! That caused me a bit of trouble, as did the fact that no one ever explained why Edward had scissors for hands. I understand that The Inventor (as he was called in the credits) died before he could give him hands, but why would he have fashioned these clunky looking scissor-type hands for him in the first place? Unanswered questions aside, I throughly enjoyed watching this (although I thought the fluffy fantasy was more enjoyable than the descent into darkness) and thought that the entire cast really pulled off a collection of good performances. Overall - 7/10
