title: A good film
content: Tim Burton's "Edward Scissorhands" (1990) is a gothic fantasy film that tells the story of an artificially created man named Edward, who has scissor blades for hands. Isolated in a Gothic mansion, Edward is discovered by a suburban Avon saleswoman, Peg Boggs, who brings him into her community.Edward's unique appearance initially fascinates the townspeople, and his talent for topiary and hairdressing makes him a local sensation. However, his scissor hands also make him an outsider, leading to misunderstandings and ultimately, rejection.The film explores themes of isolation, loneliness, and the dangers of conformity. Edward, a gentle and innocent soul, becomes a victim of the townspeople's prejudices and their own superficiality. His tragic story highlights the importance of acceptance and understanding."Edward Scissorhands" is a visually stunning film with Burton's signature dark and whimsical aesthetic. Johnny Depp delivers a captivating performance as the gentle and tragic Edward, while Winona Ryder shines as Kim, the young woman who falls in love with him. The film's poignant message about the importance of embracing individuality continues to resonate with audiences today.

title: Everything about this movie is perfect
content: Edward Scissorhands (1990) is an underrated holiday movie and Tim Burton classic in my DVD collection that my daughter and I recently rewatched on Prime. The storyline follows an artificially created young man who was made by a genius whose last wish was to give him hands but he died before he could put the finishing touches on his creation. The young man lives in hiding above a small town. When an Avon lady discovers him she brings him to her home to try and help him fit in. At first everything begins peachy but as he turns into the target of lust things get out of hand quickly...This movie is directed by icon Tim Burton (Beetlejuice) and stars Johnny Depp (Pirates of the Caribbean), Winona Ryder (Little Women), Dianne Wiest (The Birdcage), Anthony Michael Hall (Weird Science), Vincent Price (The Raven) and Alan Arkin (Argo).Everything about this movie is perfect. The sets and settings are out of control. The cast is perfectly selected and every scene Vincent Price is in makes me smile. Depp's mannerisms, facial expressions and body language is outstanding. Wiest and Hall deliver underrated performances also and this is one of my favorite Winona Ryder characters. The storyline is so unique and like nothing else ever brought to film; and for a concept that sounds outlandish, it worked. The plot unfolds well and the various subplots and supporting characters are interesting. The ending is awesome and I loved the Hall vs Depp showdown...and how can you not love the use of lawn sculptures?Overall, this is an absolute gem and an American cinematic classic. I would score this a 10/10 and consider it an absolutely must see.

title: It's weird and wonderful
content: Very enjoyable.It's funny the way we picture things in our minds. I had heard of 'Edward Scissorhands' but actually knew very little about it, typified by the fact I was expecting this to be very dark - probably just based on the seeing the cover here and there. It's much sillier than expected, but in a positive way.I do kinda end up wishing they went down a more dark/creative route, instead of relying on the novelty of having scissors as hands; though, to be fair, they do touch on the deeper side a bit. With that said, I did get a good amount of entertainment seeing this plot unfold. It's weird and wonderful.Johnny Depp is a great actor and is very good here, mainly via his facial expressions and body language. It's cool to see Winona Ryder involved, someone I've thoroughly enjoyed in more recent times in 'Stranger Things'. Alan Arkin and Anthony Michael Hall also appear.The film looks neat, as I've come to expect from Tim Burton. It has the obvious touch of Bo Welch to it, with the neighbourhood looking not too dissimilar to what Welch would create for 2003's 'The Cat in the Hat' - which I, truly, enjoyed.Undoubtedly worth a watch.

title: Really good

title: Amazing and Sad Film.
content: Edward Scissorhands id one of Tim Burton's greatest films, and all of his are great films. The movie is a very emotional and artistic movie. The movie is in a class by itself. I couldn't put this movie in any basic genre, though most Tim Burton films can't be, either. Edward Scissorhands has a very artistic and fantasy-like story, one we knew couldn't happen in real life, but it also has a lot of touches of the real world. For example, the setting of the movie is completely far fetched, yet as the story progresses, Edward finds out about many real life problems. We all do, and we all find out about the monsters in us all. Edward, the artificial and "crippled" man in the story is the only one that does not have that characteristic in him, while the rest of the cast, normal humans, are the real monsters in the film. Johnny Depp gives a stupendous and absolutely exceptional performance as Edward, a creation made by his master, the late Vincent Price. Edward's creator and master dies before he can complete him, so Edward is left with an error-scissors for hands. He lives up in a mansion until a local Avon lady brings him to her neighborhood, where he falls in love with Kim Boggs, played by Winona Ryder. What follows are extremely sad scenes of the neighborhood slowly progressing to thinking Edward is some monster, especially after a terrible decision Edward makes. Anthony Michael Hall plays the villain-type roll as Kim's boyfriend. He is the main reason why Edward is typecast as a monster in the neighborhood. The ending is very emotional, I can't say that it happy emotion either. The movie succeeds in everything it tries to accomplish. This movie proved to me that there wasn't anything Tim Burton couldn't accomplish. The movie was a flat out masterpiece. 10 out of 10!

title: Edward lives in complete solitude, his face and limbs scarred by the scissors he bears in place of hands, until one day he is introduced at last to the 'modern world'. . .
content: This is one of the most beautiful films I have ever seen. Johnny Depp is in top form in his trademark role as an outcast and he captures the character, indeed the very essence of Edward, perfectly. It is also one of Tim Burton's best films. He either makes brilliant films or terrible ones. This is definitely one of the former. The two strongest impressions from this film are of it being something uniquely wonderful and heartbreakingly sad. Although it can be seen as a comment upon society, it is, first and foremost, a story, so merely suspend your disbelief (not that you'll need to try hard to do so,) and lose yourself in the magic of the film.I love this film. . .but I expect you have already guessed that! One final thing; it contains some of the most beautiful examples of mise-en-scene that I've ever watched and is well worth seeing for that alone.

title: Funny, Heart-warming and a Proper Tearjerker
content: Everything about this film is perfectly done, the makeup is great, the costumes are amazing and the acting is superb, everything about this film comes together to create a movie that feels like a satire of suburbia at some points and a horror at others, Tim Burton created a subversive masterpiece with this film that people will be watching for years to come. The only minute detail I can fault is that the cinematography and editing feels fairly normal compared to the rest of the movie which feels lie something no one has seen before. A film that's as enjoyable for children as it is for adults I would recommend it to anybody.

title: Haunting, achingly beautiful
content: It's nearing the end of 1999, and this is *still* my favorite Tim Burton film. This is definitely my favorite modern fairy tale. The Elfman score is exquisite, the story is haunting and lovely; the film is simply magnificent.While some have criticized -Edward Scissorhands- for being too "heavy-handed" or too obviously allegorical, I think that the inherent message of the film is one that is universal enough not to be a distraction to the film's beauty. The plot and the characters are too original to evoke feelings of "been there, done that", even while it may be true that everyone has felt alienation at one time or another.The content of this film runs rampant with "Burton-isms", the clever absurdities that are Burton's trademark in films. This film does contain a lot of humor and oddity, but unlike films like  -Beetlejuice -, its story revolves around something that is not alien to anyone - love. This is a love story that breaks the heart. The originality lies in the details, and in the conclusion. It's been a long time since someone has written a fairy tale love story that doesn't end up with the beautiful girl living happily in the castle with the handsome prince. It is the ending that gets me everytime. This is a truly beautiful movie.

title: One of the most touching movies ever
content: In my opinion i think this is one of historys most touching and moving movie to date. But the movie is also about the power of true love, that can't break anything. Much to learn here, even thou the movie has its logical misses. But it is still stand out as great romantic movie. Depp is fantastic and Winona is beautiful and with Burton behind the camera, it's all perfect.

title: Pinochio, Frankenstien, I don't really think so
content: Coming from Tim Burton, you know that the story won't be something you see everyday. although, it will have elements of classic storys and classic dilemmas, but with that creative Burton twist.A very very ordinary classic 50's style American town sits at the bottom of a huge dark mountain with a scary castle on top. An Avon door to door sales women, discouraged by the fact that everyone in the town knows her and has already bought their supply of makeup, decides to travel up the mountain to try her luck there. She walks right in to the castle and finds Edward there all alone. She sees that Edward has no hands, but instead huge scissors and knives. She assumes he is helpless, and takes him home. The whole town begins to buzz about the irregular visitor. Edward lives with the sales women, and begins to show unusual artistic talents for things like sculpting bushes and cutting hair. unfortunately, Edwards nieve nature is taken advantage of and the town almost immediately all turns against him. To avoid spoiling the movie, I insist you see this movie to learn the rest of the story.I really don't think this movie is as much about Scissors or even Edward, but more about the little town, and their reaction to him. Its easy to say this is just a warped Pinnochio but instead of a little puppets who wants to be a boy, its a guy that wants hands. but, I think there is more going on here. Edwards Scissorhand's are clearly a sort of prison, but they also allow him to express himself, and really his only way to communicate. I think I watched this movie once and counted him as only haveing about 30 lines in the whole movie. For a main character, he is practically Helen Keller. I think that it could be more that he doesn't want hands as much as everyone thinks he should so he can be like them. Possibly, I think this movie is more about society. They go to great pains to show the ordinary, american dream suburb where everyones house is the same, everyone has the same dreams and hopes, Everyone goes to work at the same time, SAME SAME SAME SAME SAME. One example is what I like to call "the car ballet", where all the cars pull out of the garage at the same time and drive off. Pure symbolism. They are crying out for something new and different but, are also frightened by it. Just like a school of little scared fish, that change directions in quick motions, with no real good reason. One of my favorite examples in the movie is where a man with a prosthetic leg tells Edward to never let anyone tell him he's handicapped, later he calls Edward a cripple.Is this really about Edward wanting so badly to be like these people, or these people wanting so badly to be like Edward? Or is it simply about the worlds rejection of creativity, and diversity? Truly, these plain, boring, "ordinary," people are just as weird if not more so than Edward. I really think this story is about how the world is full of these people that have no real solo thoughts, and condemn anything different. The crumbling of human society through the effects of purity and perfection. A sad commentary on the current human condition, or lack there of. Love thy common man? only if he is just like you.Does Edward want to be "a real boy"? I think he probubly already is more than anyone else in the movie.

title: A dedication to the handicapped
content: Truly, Edward Scissorhands is one of Tim Burton's masterpieces.  He mixes mystery, fear, magic, legend, incomprehension and love.  Mainly, the relation between Kim Boggs (Ryder) and Edward Scissorhands (Depp) goes far beyond any imagination could have thought before (no wonder why they dated after the making of the movie).  In a few words, a contemporary fairy tale of how a man-made robot could have become the model of human perfection, until a tragic event crumbles everything down, and how the love of a girl gives him the inspiration to carry on with his life to bring beauty and happiness to the people on the town. Every time I see this movie, it makes me think that life is short and that you must have to get the most out of it...never lose time.

title: Classic but a goodie.
content: This movie still terrifies me as much as it did as a child. Good movie for good chills and to watch something different.

title: A Beautifully Arranged and Emotional Film
content: One of my all time favorite movies, Tim Burton directs another one of his outstanding pieces. There's a marvelous cast playing imaginative characters, especially Johnny Depp, who in the movie plays Edward, and says only a few lines, but was still best for the part and really gets you close to him while watching the movie.Along with Danny Elfman's beautiful score, the plot is well written with touching scenes that that are really meaningful. And there are of course a few funny scenes that can really crack you up. And most of them are quite simple too.This movie truly shows how powerful movies can be. I swear, this is one of the most emotional films I have ever experienced watching, and it got me crying for quite a while in the end of the film.I sincerely do recommend this film to anyone who has a big heart, is a fan of Tim Burton, enjoy's a good cry, or would like to see what love can truly be. This isn't one of those romantic chick flicks such as "The Notebook" or the "Titanic" that makes you cry. This is an incredible film that is much more beyond that, and that will remain in you mind for a long long time.

title: Beauty and the Beast.
content: Tim Burton has updated an old tale of the misunderstood and scary-looking beast (Edward) and his love relationship with an incomparable beauty (Kim or Winona Ryder).  The tale is modernized (sort of) into a suburbia America setting with 60's styles houses, clothing, cars, and people.  The reason this movie is so likable is simply because it interweave's romanticism and darkness with bits of comedy to relieve the tension of the viewer.  This dark fable puts chills down your spine (e.g. when Edward first steps out of the darkness of the attic to meet Peg) while at the same time fills your heart with an equal mixture of happiness and sorrow.  In addition, Burton's  picture was filmed with great elegance.  Who can forget the scene when Edward is carving the ice sculptor and Kim is dancing in the snow he has created?  The ending of the movie is not as melancholy as everyone believes.  It is revelatory about who the real monster is.  This movie can obviously be compared with other tales of individuals who were also outcasts in their society such as Frankenstein and Burton's other masterpiece, Batman.  This work of Burton's is his personal statement to all pariahs who have ever been spurned by the greater populus.

title: A tragic love story
content: JohnnyDepp looks into his innocent, affectionate eyes and asks, who can escape?Bold and unrestrained, the way of service is steeped in Tim burton's whimsy.

title: Simply Magical
content: The score for this wonderfully orchestrated fantasy goes beyond words. The essence of the characterization of Edward is truly one of the great masterpieces of Tim Burton. The emotional depth of the Grand Finale Selection is without words. Truly, Burton's Finest.

title: An Imaginative World Only Possible By Tim Burton!
content: Edward Scissorhands (1990, Dir. Tim Burton)In a castle high on top of a hill, an inventor had created his greatest creation. He had created Edward, a near complete person. The creator died before he could finish Edward's hands. Instead, Edward is left with metal scissors for hands. Edward always lived alone, that is until a kind lady called Peg discovers Edward and welcomes him into his home. At first, everyone welcomes Edward into the community, but soon things begin to take a change for the worst.'Edward Scissorhands' is one of those breathtaking pieces of cinema, which open up the imagination completely. Directed by Tim Burton, Music Composed by Danny Elfman and starring the wonderful Johnny Depp. All the ingredients to make not just a perfect Burton movie, but an overall perfect movie. The movie is amazingly created with a tale which you would have not heard before. The costumes are fascinating and the casting is superb. What a better person to work with, for Vincent Price on his last big theatrical role. What really stands out though, is the amazing colours placed throughout the film. Tim Burton goes for his usual dark scenery, but once away from the creepy old castle, the screen comes alive with every colour imaginable. If you haven't seen this film yet, then you don't know what your missing."Dad, did you see where Edward went?" - Kim (Winona Ryder)"I don't know. He just waltzed down the street." - Bill (Alan Arkin)

title: Exquisite
content: A simply wonderful film.  I am neither a goth or a Johnny Depp fan, but this film oozes quality.  Good performances from all concerned, but the real master is the man behind the camera.  Tim Burton's finest hour without a doubt.  Absolutely stunning.Easy to see how he got the Batman job (such a shame for hindsight though)

title: Burton's most touching piece - a dark and creative fairytale
content: Edward (Depp), born with scissors for hands, is brought into the local village and becomes the talk of the town.God bless Tim Burton. Who in their right minds would take a fairy tale and include a man with scissors for hands? Burton's sheer strangeness continues after his beautiful Beetlejuice and Batman in this darkly colourful fantasy drama and throws the fairytale convention out of the window. Burton is an inspiration to the film industry, a man who does everything differently and there is no one else out there like him, and his finally cut creation, inspired by one of his own drawings, is a sentimental spark in his collection, his most touching to date.For those fairytale lovers out there don't worry. This 1990 picture follows the convention of an outsider trying to make it in a land of troubles and difference, also including a beautiful girl and a touching if slightly obvious love story.Like many Burton films he gives us a wonderful imaginative other world.The oppositions encoded into this drama are fantastic. From the cold hearted dark home of Edward's to the unbelievably organised and colourful suburban town below, Burton's imagination allows viewers to see two opposite worlds living next door to each other.These settings are exquisite in establishing the characters. The similar styled houses are those tidy and sophisticated homes you expect the rich and posh to live and sure enough all the middle aged gossip loving women live next door to one another. Their tidiness and appearances create that stereotypical shallow middle aged woman that shapes the story in so many ways.The darkness of Edward's home is brought to life through the cold machinery. The inventor's house is a dark walled, miserable and negative creation and marks the quietness and shyness of central character Edward.Who would believable Captain Jack Sparrow and Edward are portrayed by the same actor? You see Jack's cockiness provoking Elizabeth Swan with his quiet ruthlessness, and then you see Edward hiding his face from Kim with his Scissorhands. How Depp was never nominated for as Oscar for this performance will rage on until the end of time. Words cannot describe how he makes this character.Good support is given by Ryder, West, hall and beautiful protagonist Joyce is created by Kathy Baker's ultimate fake charm.Burton has waved his wand again to cast a dark and imaginative spell over the conventional fairytale and turned it into a bubbling dark and touching fantasy

title: Once Again: Awesome
content: Tim Burton strikes again in this beautiful fairy tale about Edward, a man with scissors for hands. This is the second Tim Burton movie I've seen, and this one is just as good as the other one. He is great at showing the emotions of the characters in this film. It'll go from funny to sad to another emotion so smoothly. Johnny Depp is great at this character. He brings the sweetness to Edward. He also shows how hard it is for Edward to survive with scissor hands.Again, good facial emotion. Winona Rider was good at showing the change in feelings she feels towards Edward. Danny Elfman also brings the perfect musical score to set the mood. The only thing I did not like about the movie was the pastel colors of the town. They were ugly!! But, all in all, go see this movie. It brings out the person in you that has always wanted to fit in a certain way but couldn't.

title: Excellent...
content: This movie is to Tim Burton what "Pulp Fiction" was to Tarantino, and "Taxi Driver" to Scorsese.  A definitive directorial vision, put artfully and beautifully on film.  The story, apparently, is a metaphorical reflection of the lonely childhoods of both Burton and screenwriter Caroline Thompson.  The role of Edward put Johnny Depp on the Hollywood map as an artist to be considered for roles of depth and substance.  Burton's direction is flawless, oddly moving, and visually stunning, with the same eerie and head-tilting weirdness that audiences have come to expect from his material.  Long time collaborator Danny Elfman provides a score that ranks among his very best.  The socio-political observations, citations, and commentary that the story and movie provide are both on the ball and thought provoking.  As a character, Edward's tragic innocence, awesome talent, and extraordinary imagination are brought to life with remarkable sensitivity by Depp.  Winona Ryder, Alan Archan, Diane Weist, and Anthony Michael Hall are wonderful in their respective supporting roles. A film that will be remembered.  10/10.

title: A funny light-hearted but also sad and tragic tale about a man-made "monster" with a human soul
content: Edward Scissorhands is a classic. It's a funny, light-hearted feel-good movie that actually ends up being quite sad and tragic. The design of Edward's castle/mansion is so cool, it definitely has that Tim Burton aesthetic to it. Edwards tale is one of a fish out of water, one of a man-made monster trying to fit into society. In reality, he's a gentle monster with a pure soul and a kind heart. One could argue that he's probably more human than the actual humans that end up upending his life. It's so sad because Edward has such a good heart and means well, but society and people keep putting him down and making him out to be the villain. Edward also can't help the way he looks, he was almost destined to a future of torment and isolation.It's a movie about abandonment, loneliness and being an outcast. It's about a person that wishes to fit in and wishes for human interaction, but unfortunately society can't help but deem him a monster. The movie also highlights the utopian suburban life, the mob mentality and how quickly people can turn due to gossip, rumors and lies. Almost how the town turned on the monster in Frankenstein. It has a very bittersweet ending, but you can't help but feel so sad for Edward. In essence it's a movie about real life people who look deformed or scary, but have the gentlest and kindest of souls. Highly recommended. Raw score: 8/10.

title: Tim Burton fans should watch it! (Even if they aren't into romantic movies.)
content: I'm going to say this: I'm not a giant fan of the romance genre. It's either cliched or boring. There are some exceptions like Disney films, Grease, Fault in Our Stars, Shape of Water, and this film. This is one of my favorite Tim Burton movies next to Beetlejuice! The performances are amazing, the music is spine-chilling, and the movie, as a whole, just feels magical! I cannot think of a single flaw that this movie has. This is a tearjerker film that every movie fan should experience at least once in their life.

title: Maturity education.
content: After I watched Beetlejuice I disliked the movie so much I did lose faith in Tim Burton a lot. Beetlejuice is clearly the work of some 6 years old person who had just power enough to direct a movie with a huge budget - nothing more. But if this movie wasn't one of the Johnny Depp movies I honestly wouldn't watch it as he is my favourite actor of all time. To be honest I don't think I would like this movie that much without Johnny Depp but I cannot deny anything else is so in perfect harmony with each other so this movie really deserves 10/10 so we gotta thank Caroline Thompson for such an epic movie.Without spoiling you in detail this is the story of a person who is different. The moral of the lesson is you can use your difference to make a good difference in the world and you can have a good life no matter what by using your difference. This movie is very realistic about how people are and how society works therefore in that regard this movie is a good documentary about humanity and it felt like you watching a documentary of animals in a humorous way. Unlike Beetlejuice this movie doesn't make fun of people living a tragedy but instead it can be humorous in a mature way so it's not childish like Beetlejuice.The another moral lesson you learn is no matter who you are, you are nothing when you are being a toxic person therefore even Edward was liked by people despite his difference just because personality-wise he is a good person while a normal person was hated even though he is a normal person just because he was toxic no matter he tried to be a hero. That point of view alone is very wise because so many people try to be normal and hide their differences even though their differences are their strengths. Also so many people bark like a dog and are selfish to get what they want but society shut them up eventually which is what happened to the normal guy in this movie. So it's actually interesting to watch a movie that doesn't have a hero and evil. The difference between two opposite people in this movie is just a matter of behaving wrongly like a kid and being realistic by being mature. It's also interesting to watch a movie that doesn't focus on a sense of morality but it just focuses on what's being wise and caring about the win-win situation and what happens to immature people.So my favourite person in the movie is Jim. He is one of the rare characters who is a real mature and wise person therefore it felt like watching Donnie Darko's parents. I really needed to gain my sanity after dealing with kids for a long time these days so much I had to watch a mature person get my senses back therefore this movie was also like medicine for my mind.Only bad aspect of the movie is how Winona Ryder is a bad actress. It's actually insult to even call her an actress. Like Leonardo Dicaprio every character she plays as feels like the same person which for me is a sign of bad acting. An actor/actress should be the character, not making the character like their real self therefore Winona Ryder breaks immersion a lot but fortunately she is not in the movie much. On the other hand Johnny Depp, Brad Pitt and Evan Rachel Wood knows how to act.

title: Praise for one of Tim Burton's best.
content: Director Tim Burton uses his trademark Gothic perspective to bring to life this film. And the result is excellent. Sometimes I don't know which is more terrifying; the dark, unsettling world of Edward or the pink and blue, bland world of conformity he is thrust into. The movie itself is driven by Johnny Depp's powerful presence. You can't help but feel strongly for his title character, wishing that he could move past the impossible: trying to achieve acceptance from a world that he could not understand. Winona Ryder is Edward's love interest, and really this is her only great acting, aside from Girl, Interrupted. This movie will stay in your mind for a long time. 4 1/2 out of 5 stars, not to mention arguably Depp's and Ryder's best performances.

title: Beautifully Told
content: When I first saw it as a kid, I didn't really understand it much except that there was a man with scissorhands who got adopted and kissed a pretty girl. Watching it as an adult, I realized that there are actually deeper meanings in this film.The story is told very simply, and it opens with an old lady telling a bedtime story to her granddaughter. The story is about a man named Edward with scissorhands. Edward was an unfinished product of an aging inventor. Years later a nosy but kind-hearted neighbor finds out about him and adopts him into their home.It's a simple tale with a lot of deep meanings. It's a tale that shows us one of the worst sides of human nature. Despite some evil in this world, the story also shows us that there are always people with genuine and good hearts. Edward is also a relatable character, misunderstood and alone. It's a beautiful story, really.Highly recommended.

title: THIS MOVIE CAN BE BETTER
content:
This movie is very well done. But some flaws are very noticeable. For example:
1. The music is not very well proportioned.2. The blood can be seen to be fake.3. Villages are not realistic: I know that American villages are like villages in cartoons. The houses are all the same, and the interiors are very lightly decorated.This movie is pretty good overall.

title: Beautifully sad...
content: I just saw this movie for this first time since I viewed it in in the theater back when it came out in 1990.  I was 17 then and maybe really didn't appreciate it as much since there were no big explosions.  This time around I saw it for what a truly beautiful and sad movie it is.  Edward is menacing to look at at first, but Depp brings true childlike innocence to the character with his face.  Watching the town turn on him is like watching a child being tormented.  The relationship between him and Kim is touching to watch as it changes, as is how the end shows us how the town changed Edward.I gave this movie 8/10.  I probably would have given it 9/10 if it were not for the "Battle Royal" at the end.  It seemed kinda shoe-horned in if you ask me. Didn't really seem to fit the theme of the rest of the movie.  (I'm not talking about the prologue, that was cool).Lastly, a lot of folks have commented on how all the houses are solid colors. Actually during the fifties many homes came close to that.  The idea was that it made it easier to paint.  Obviously Burton took it to another level, but just FYI.

title: THE MOST WONDERFUL MOVIE OF ALL TIMES
content: "Edward Scissorhands" is magical, it is wonderful. Tim Burton directed this masterpiece for all the people who believe in magic and dreams... thanks for your beautiful fairy-tale, mister Burton.

One of the best movies ever made. Watching it for the first time was an unmatched experience, and even when I was younger I was able to understand the beauty in it. It's, in my opinion, one of Tim Burton's best works, and severely underrated within the genre. Edwards story never fails to make my heart ache, and Johnny was the perfect cast for the role; Edward truly adds so much to the beauty of this story.I feel as if this movie can be appreciated by a wide array of viewers and is timeless in that way. Though surface level, the story seems like any other, but I think it holds so much more meaning then that.

title: Creative
content: One of Tim Burton's best movies. Original, Creative.

title: A bittersweet parable about conformity(possible spoiler?)
content: I love most of Tim Burton's movies, but I would have to say that "Edward Scissorhands" is my favorite. The art direction and set design are all wildly imaginative and a treat to behold. The hauntingly emotional score by Danny Elfman is also his best IMO.And at the center is the fantastic, indispensable Johnny Depp in the title role. Edward is a character for whom very little can be expressed verbally;Depp uses body language and(above all) his eyes to depict emotion, and it works perfectly.Though there are moments of humor(ie Edward and the water bed)this movie is ultimately a sad elegy for all of those that are ostracized by the "normal people". The highest emotional moment(for me) is when Kim(Winona Ryder) and Edward part;she's finally awakened to genuine emotion,but it is just too late."Edward Scissorhands" is without a doubt my favorite Burton movie.

title: Frankenstein's monster in 20th Century suburbia
content: What if Frankenstein's monster had met the Avon lady instead of an angry mob with torches and pitchforks? Would things really have turned out differently? That's the premise for this charming fable. Edward is the ultimate man-child. Unlike so many other man-children, he doesn't bear a special message of hope for mankind. He doesn't possess supernatural powers. He's simply confused, awkward, and open-hearted. He's brilliant at some things, but when he makes mistakes or doesn't conform, disapproval falls on him hard. Ryder points out in the extras that her character's reaction to Ed is the only honest one. Everyone else projects their expectations onto him because he's a blank slate. He's sexy. He's a genius. He's a devil. He's a scissor-wielding maniac. His love is as open and honest as a puppy dog's, and when he's at his lowest, the neighbor's dog is the only one who approaches him. When he's a persecuted and hounded criminal, it's a black cop (the only black person in town, it seems) who cuts him a break. The movie suggests that behind the veneer of suburban civility, we're not as far removed from torch-wielding Transylvanian peasants as we'd like to think.

title: GREAT GREAT GREAT!!!
content: It was a great movie.I seen a lot of movies and that has to be top five.What makes a good movie is the actors/actresses facial expressions on the set, and that is what makes the movie seem real and gives off feelings and johnny depp did that, which made the movie even better.I love the movie because its not every day you see a movie of a lonely man with sissorhands. its unique and thats another reason its better than other movies.a lot of movies are the same but this one is different. the set was awesome and the cast was awesome everything about it was great.the actors/actresses were awesome because of their talent. they made this a great movie and i cant get enough of it.

title: A portrait of an offbeat humanity
content: Edward Scissorhands to me represented the inhumanity of the mass, the complacency of people when faced with the troubles of society, of the individual. In the beginning, everyone loved Edward, everyone profited from him. However, at the first sign of trouble the walls began to collapse. The crowd who joined to embrace Scissorhands turned against him as his flaws became apparent as the eerie and offbeat hedges he sculpted and that everyone seemed to enjoy.A scene I can recall but that seemed to make this point was the confrontation between Kim's (Winona Ryder) boyfriend Jim (Anthony Michael Hall) and Scissorhands/Depp. Jim, an embodiment of the cruelty of youth, was shoving Edward, who slipped and sliced Ryder/Kim's hand. He then chased Scissorhands away, while the contented father character, within earshot, continued to set up his Christmas decorations on the roof, confused about why the protagonist fled. That illustrated to me the father's inability to grasp what was beyond the obvious, and his neglect of his would-be stepson, the decorations a facade of an easy-going everyday.Another point I liked was the end, after the mob had decided Edwards fate. What struck me was the fat woman, who casually said after the dramatic scene she wanted to go home, the first of the mob to disperse. It seemed cold, like a dog-eat-dog sort of scenario, and was a slice into the veil of civility people use to make for smooth but one-dimensional interaction. I think there's a difference between niceness and intention, and sincerity. Everyone's relation to the main character was this superficial show, and the almost mute Scissorhands was sort of left a mystery to the viewers, except when revealed by the only true friend he had, Kim.The film overall related, to me, to the illusory layers of optimism that shield people from all the shortcomings of the world around-- and can be contrasted with the truer reality of mishap and conflict that usually lie beneath the surface, in an imperfect world. It seems to face the dilemma of whether to choose popcorn and bubblegum, or take things for what they are. Like in the movie, most seem to find it difficult to try this-- or to take the experience in stride-- and that's the inhumanity of it: the coldness, like ignoring a homeless person during winter-- and I found the film a very interesting depiction of this, even more so because of Burton's strange creativity.

title: Beauty
content: Tim Burton has a knack for, and perhaps a habit of(but as long as the movies are great, what's the harm?) making Gothic films, centered around a misunderstood outcast who is or will be distrusted by townspeople. He really understands the characters, and he helps us to understand them, too. This is an utterly beautiful film. I'm not sure it's possible to watch this and not be affected emotionally. The characters are exceptionally well-written, and portrayed. The acting is basically all good. Depp is astounding. As with The Penguin of Batman Returns, I wasn't really watching the actor, I was watching the character. The writing is great, throughout. The pacing is just about flawless. The humor is magnificent, and seldom harsh or unnecessary. Some things in this are perhaps at least a little above what children should watch. Some language, and suggestive dialog and actions. The unclear time period is well done... this could take place today, or decades ago. The use of color is expertly done. The film is amazing. I recommend this to anyone who can look beyond the surface. 8/10

title: An overrated but charming and eventually very moving fairy tale set in modern-day suburbia
content: There have been many film collaborations between filmmaker Tim Burton and actor Johnny Depp, but it all started with "Edward Scissorhands", a successful dark fantasy movie. I was a preschooler when this was released, and I remember hearing about the film and seeing a bit of it within the next few years after that. However, I never actually sat down to watch the 1990 blockbuster until 2006. At the time, I wasn't sure what I thought of the first hour or so, but found it very powerful later on! After a little over four years, I've seen the hit modern-day fairy tale again, from start to finish. I still certainly wasn't as impressed as so many other viewers definitely have been over the years, but still think it's a good first Burton/Depp collaboration.Edward is an artificial human being who lives in a mansion up the hill from a suburban neighbourhood. This mansion was the home of his inventor, who died just before he got to finish his invention, leaving Edward incomplete, with scissors for hands! One day, a local Avon representative named Peg Boggs is not having any luck with her sales, and decides to go to the mansion to try and make a sale, not knowing who lives there. Up on the hill, she finds nobody in sight until she reaches the top floor, where she meets Edward, and it seems he has never been off the mansion property! Peg takes him back home with her, and he stays with the Avon representative, her husband Bill, young son Kevin, and teenage daughter Kim at their house. The artificial being is admired by most of the neighbours, but Kim's boyfriend, a thug named Jim, does not think too highly of him, and he could lead Edward into a load of trouble!At the beginning of the film, we see a grandmother about to tell her granddaughter the story of Edward Scissorhands. This elderly woman is not played very well by a young actress in makeup, trying to speak in an elderly voice. After the story begins, the part where Peg Boggs discovers the mansion and searches for someone inside is a little tedious, but the mansion is a fascinating location, and the scene showing her meeting Edward for the first time can certainly grab viewers. Edward, played wonderfully by Johnny Depp, stands out as a likable character, but some of the other characters are not portrayed so well, especially Esmeralda, the Christian fanatic who thinks Edward is from hell. I honestly don't get this character! Is she meant to be funny?! If so, she's not. She's just weird, absurd, and annoying! Good thing she only has four scenes! There are also some fairly sappy moments in this film. However, most of the movie is well done. It's usually intriguing showing the protagonist's relationship with the people in the neighbourhood, and there are some other good performances, such as Winona Ryder as Kim, Vincent Price as Edward's inventor in flashback sequences, and Anthony Michael Hall as the despicable Jim. Later on, the film gets very dark, intense, and often heartbreaking, and I've never seen a character harder not to hate than the one Hall plays here! The tension and emotion at this point are unforgettable!This first Burton/Depp collaboration is probably thought by many to be their best. It does seem to be more popular than most of the others, but I have to disagree. Unlike some people, I've found some severe flaws here, but overall, I still think it's a very good film which deserved its success, even if it's not as great as its reputation suggests. I would say the film is most effective after the first hour or so, which was what I thought the first time as well, but I think the movie as a whole was better for me the second time. It's probably a good thing I didn't see much of "Edward Scissorhands" as a kid. What I saw at the time didn't hurt, with Edward accidentally puncturing a waterbed and struggling to try and eat with his scissor hands, but it might have gotten to be a bit too much for me near the end, especially with the Jim character. Well, it was rated PG-13. I certainly wouldn't recommend this for kids, except maybe older ones, but for many adolescents and adults, I'm sure it's a worthwhile fantasy drama, with a bit of humour.

title: for the season it was an excellent movie!
content: People should stop being picky about movies that were made with less technology and appreciate the script more!It's a perfect movie to watch before Christmas with the whole family together.

title: A masterpiece
content: Edward Scissorhands is one of my all-time favorite movies, and is something I could watch over and over again.Here, Johnny Depp gives his best performance. It's amazing how he went from a bad boy role in Cry Baby with a sad, vulnerable character in Edward Scissorhands.This is also Burton's best work. If this is the first film you watch by Tim Burton, you will think he is a fantastic director. Danny Elfman's score also helped the film because it's happy at the right times, and it's sad and mellow at the right times.Overall, the story was very heartfelt and emotional, the score was amazing, the acting was superb, and the suburban setting gave the film a fairy tale feel to it. Because the film is like a fairy tale.Rating: 9.5/10

title: A surreal and beautiful modern fairytale that's a cut above the rest
content: Edward Scissorhands is a surreal and beautiful film. It's amazing how Tim Burton can present such a bizarre world in a way that seems completely acceptable. And the unique sets, costumes, colors, and characters make the whole viewing experience feel immersive. There's a lot of praise going towards Johnny Depp's portrayal of Edward, as it should, but Dianne Wiest really shines as Peg. She's fantastic as the optimistic maternal figure. In fact, everyone in this strange pastel suburbia enriches the film with their offbeat performances. Edward Scissorhands is a modern fairytale that's a cut above the rest.

title: A gentle, whimsical, twisted, imaginative, touching, sad, funny, striking, visually stunning treat!
content: EDWARD SCISSORHANDS was only a modest hit at the box-office when it was released in 1990 ($54 million U.S. gross) but it has garnered many fans and supporters over the last decade. And deservedly so. It is a gentle, whimsical, twisted, wildly imaginative, touching, sad, funny, striking, visually stunning treat from Tim Burton and his best film if you ask me (though A NIGHTMARE BEFORE CHRISTMAS, which he produced but not directed, gives this a run for its money). Sure, he's got bigger hits (BEETLEJUICE, BATMAN), but none are as good as matching their amazing visuals with equally interesting characters as this film. Johnny Depp and Winona Ryder(as always) are terrific, as is the Dianne Wiest.

title: loved it
content: The movie is kind of naive, fool, or even idiotic... but I really enjoyed it. It's a classic that is partly fairy tale, partly horror, partly comedy, partly drama... Usually, I do not enjoy movies that are such a mix, but Edward Scissorhands is a great one.
Interesting film it was classic when I was little child. Now I couldn't watch it because of quality.

title: One of the most touching Movies
content: I don't know exactly what it is about this Movie that appeals to me. It could be the touching story, or the wonderful sets, or the great acting by Dianne Wiest, Johnny Depp, Winona Ryder, and Alan Arkin. I guess it's all of them!

title: One of the greatest characters of all times in a weak storyline.
content: "Edward Scissorhands" is a movie that achieves greatness in so many ways. The title character is more sympathetic than "Frankenstein".  The "creator" scenes are more mesmerizing than the cuckoo clock scene in "Pinnochio".  I could go on...I really think Tim Burton deserves a lifetime achievement award for the invention of the character.  Notice the scars on his face look like permanent tears?Dianne Wiest is my favorite "mom" from 80's movies.  Winona Rider is in a limited role, but she does a great job, and looks very princess-like with blonde hair.  Alan Arkin plays a perfect dry-humored "dad".Of course the problem here is a plot that is basically on a TV-movie level. It's a basic exploitation story where everyone in town makes Edward a hero, then tear him down.  Such a great character deserves much more.
